ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Super interesting subject matter. Class discussion was often frustrating, though, and a bit unfocused. I expect this will be better next time around, and frankly if you've never studied anything like this before its worth it.
A fantastic, but high-level class investigating imperialism in the Middle East. You definitely need a previous background in Middle Eastern history, but I highly recommend this course.

GLBL 362 is an excellent course on the history of imperialism in the Middle East. The readings are really wonderful, covering a wide range of both theoretical and historical material. I would definitely recommend it.
if this is your thing - insurgency, state building, etc. if you're less poli sci minded like me, I would look elsewhere. great in focusing on Maghreb though, so few yale MMES classes do that!

I would certainly recommend this class to students interested in a multifaceted approach to the complex and relevant questions of state-building and insurgency in the greater Middle East.So long as no clear answers or political objectives are expected, this is truly a rewarding course.
Definitely take it if you're interested in the material. It is a good introduction to this subject in all its dimensions, from history to contemporary.

There were some moments whenI really hated this class (mostly when discussions in class got hijacked by a few people and taken in a direction I really wasn't interested in) but it probably changed the way I think about the world and the Middle East more than every class I have taken at Yale except postcolonial theory. So... take it I guess?
